titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Thursday.

A miscellaneous Stanza, James Baxter was here, and promised to examine the Registry of Deeds in Boston for the Title deed from James Faxon to his father, of the Woodlot which I have agreed to purchase of him— I answered a Letter from James Taylor of Hampton Valley near Emmitsburg, Frederick County Maryland, who thinks he has discovered a new method of squaring the Circle. His method is actually new to me—and he makes 8862. the length of the side a square, of equal contents with those of a Circle, the Diameter of which is one— I verified the accuracy of this calculation as near as 886226. I am also poring in the Astronomics of Manilius— Charles went to Boston, and did not return till Evening— Mrs Nowlan, the same for Confession, upon all Saints day— After dinner I planted a row of Acorns, Nettle-berries, Beachnuts and Apple seeds; and had seven Horse-Chesnuts, transplanted from the Nursery, along side of the Wall, bordering upon D. Greenleaf— I walked down to my brother’s Widow’s— Paid her 20 dollars for the wood sold by Deacon Spear, on the farm rented by Caleb Hollis— Our departure for Washington is approaching, and I am wasting almost all my time.
2. IV.30 Friday.

Two miscellaneous Stanza’s this Morning— I poach in Manilius; with an indistinct idea, that something amusing and instructive may be made out of him, but groping in the dark for a plan— The parallel between judicial Astrology and phrenology might if well treated be presented in a very striking light—and Dr Spurzheim is turning all our meditative brains by his Lectures— Since the days of Whitfield there has not been such a frenzy. James Baxter brought me a copy of a Deed from James Faxon to his father in 1784 of the wood lot, which I have agreed to purchase of him— He said he would have it surveyed, and sent me word afterwards that Mr Humphrey has promised to come to-morrow Morning and make the Survey— I visited my garden and Nursery— Planted in the Nursery two rows of acorns, Beach Nuts, apple seeds, and Nettle Berries, and had transplanted seven more Horse Chesnuts. Planted also one whole dwarf-tree Apple. These garden and Nursery Visits, absorb almost the whole morning after Breakfast. Mr T. Greenleaf and G. W. Beale came and examined the Town Library, with my Son Charles, at the Office; but did not finish— I received a Letter from Dr Waterhouse which I answered— The Biography is suspended.
3. V. Saturday.

Two miscellaneous Stanza’s— Received this Morning by the Mail, the first Copy of Dermot MacMorrogh, printed handsomely; but on cursorily casting my eye over it, I found several gross errors of the Press— A fearful moment for my reputation— At 8 O’Clock I rode to James Baxter’s, and thence to the Woodlot that I have agreed to purchase of him— Found him and Mr Humphrey already there— I went with them entirely round the lot which is partly covered with wood and partly bare— The shrubbery and Briars are so thick in part of it as made it almost impossible to pass through them— Mr Humphrey will have the plan made out by next Tuesday— I walked home two Miles and a half. Charles and his wife went to Boston and returned late to dine— After dinner I visited my Garden and Nursery— Planted two rows of Acorns, Beech Nuts and Apple seeds and four Ellis Apples between the seedling Apple-trees transplanted from the Box in the front yard— My time will fail me again for doing a tenth part of what I intended— I must hope to transplant again in the Spring— And leave how much undone— Mr Beale was here this Evening, and brought a plan for the projected School-House—to cost 4000 dollars—with Wooden pillars— This Evening I received from Lord a package, with twenty copies of Dermot—one of which I gave to Mr Beale.
4. V. Sunday.

The vein of Poetry runs slackening. Heard Mr Peter Whitney in the Morning from Proverbs 3.5. “Trust in the Lord with all thine heart; and lean not unto thine own understanding” and in the afternoon from 1. Timothy 1.11. “The glorious gospel of the blessed God.” Louisa C. Smith dined with us— My time was much abridged in correcting the errors of the Press in my Poem and making up eight or ten copies to send to some of my friends— Mr Degrand came out from Boston with Mr. W. W. Clapp, publisher of the Evening Gazette a weekly Newspaper published every Saturday Evening; and issued in part on Sunday Mornings— They brought the result of the Election at Philadelphia, last Friday of Electors of President and Vice-President— The ticket opposed to Jackson had a majority of seven or eight hundred more than at the late election for Governor. The result is nevertheless extremely problematical— Degrand said he had read my Poem last Evening, and thought it the best thing I had ever written— In Mr Clapp’s paper there are several extracts both from the preface, and the poem, with a commentary upon the whole favourable, and criticism of no very high order— They took tea here, and said something of a project talked of they knew not by whom, to place me in the Senate U.S. instead of Mr Webster. I read Saurin’s Sermon on the fear of Death.
5. V. Monday

My Morning Musings are broken up; and I am beginning preparations for departure— Charles went to Boston and did not return till Evening— I wrote to Lord, asking him to make a list of errata to the poem of Dermot, upon a small slip of paper to attach to the copies yet to be distributed. Josiah Adams was here, and has purchased for me three Lots of standing wood, at the Sales on Lemuel Brackett’s Lot— He promised to have them cut and carted for me in the Winter— Deacon Spear was here also, and is to sell my wood on the Borland lot next Friday. I despatched by Mail a large number of Public Documents, and a few copies of Dermot. Mr and Mrs Frothingham made us a short visit from Boston— Mr Frothingham gave me a printed copy of a Sermon by him called Barabbas preferred— I visited my Garden and Nursery; but they are covered with Seaweed, and the weather has become so raw that there is no pleasure in planting— My wife and Charles’s went to take tea, at my brother’s Widow’s— I walked with Charles there in the Evening— Mr G. W. Beale was there— I executed there a Power of Attorney to John M. Gourgas to receive the Rents of the Braintree and Medford Farms, and to pay over the net proceeds of the rents to Mrs A. Adams— I authorized him also to settle with the Lowell Railway Corporation, for damages to the Medford Farm.
6. V. Tuesday.

Mr Gourgas came this Morning, and I paid him the bills for the Books I purchased at the Auction Sale of my brother’s Library, and the Articles which I purchased at the Sale here. He thought it might be necessary to add to the Power I gave him authority to give a Deed to the Lowell Rail-Road Company, of the Land they have taken from the Farm at Medford, but I thought if a Deed should be necessary, I could execute it myself. I asked him for the Title Deeds of the two Farms, but he was unwilling to give them, he knew not why; for he said I ought ultimately to have them— I rode with John Kirke to Dedham— Met President Quincy at the Probate-Office, precisely at Noon— Presented the 7th Account of the Executors of my father’s Will, with the Vouchers— The judge administered the Oath, and accepted the account to be filed— I called at the Registry of Deeds and took out two Deeds, which have been there two or three years to be recorded— I then went with Mr Quincy, and dined with his two Aunts Mrs Dowse and Mrs Shaw—widows and twins— Mr Lamson the Minister of the Parish, and his wife, a daughter of Artemas Ward, were there. I returned home about 5. P.M— Weather Raw and Chilly— Elizabeth C. Adams was at our house— My wife quite unwell— Confined to her chamber the whole day— James Baxter was here and brought Mr Humphrey’s Survey of the wood lot— I wrote a Deed, and gave it to him to be executed.
7. IV. Wednesday.

I wrote to R. Rush and Saml. L. Southard. Charles, his wife and infant daughter left us this morning, and returned to their Residence at Boston for the Winter— Mr Peter Whitney, and afterwards Mr T. Greenleaf and Mr Beale visited me— Mr Beale was somewhat anxious to commence the Execution of the Plan for a School-House, which he has procured— I thought it would be more expedient to compare it with another plan of a building in two Stories— I returned to Mr Whitney, his Parish Register which he had borrowed. My wife went to Boston, with our daughter, but returned home to dinner— I was occupied the whole day and evening in despatching Public Documents and copies of Dermot; and in settling Bills and making other preparations for departure— James Baxter brought me this morning the deed of the lot of woodland which I have purchased of him executed by himself and his wife, and acknowledged only by himself—a practice so Common that I suppose it to be legal in this Commonwealth. I paid him 541. dollars and 70 Cents, for the lot, being 28 Acres and 42 rods.
8. Thursday. IV.— To Boston.

At 8 O’Clock this morning, my wife with my Son John’s Child Louisa, Mrs Nowlan, Mrs Pitts, and John Kirk left our house at Quincy with our Carriage and pair of horses for Providence on our way to Washington— Half an hour afterwards I took a Seat in Gillet’s Stage, and came in to my Son Charles’s House 3. Hancock Avenue, Boston— I called at Mr. A. H. Everett’s, and while I was with him Mr Hallett the Editor of the Anti-Masonic Newspaper the Advocate came in— They are much disappointed by the Prospects of the Presidential Election—and spoke also much of the political movements in South-Carolina— I next called upon Mr Lord and bespoke some further copies of Dermot— There is a total silence about it in the federal newspapers, which Lord says is owing to their being so much engaged in electioneering, but for which there are other causes— Lord told me he expected to have very soon a call for a second Edition, and that he had printed 250 Copies extra of the greatest part of the Poem— “Aequam memento servare mentem”— Lord gave me a copy of the Choir— The musical Collection in which he at first intended to insert my hymn and Psalm— But they are not there. He said he reserves them for a publication of a higher order— I must be patient— I dined and spent the Evening with Charles in his family—settled with him my Quincy tax-bill for this year— I sent and engaged a passage to Providence in a Stage to go at 5 to-morrow Morning.
9. IV:15. Friday— To Providence— Steamboat President. Sound.

I was called up at a quarter past four, and before five was in the Stage for Providence— Three quarters of an hour riding round the Streets and taking in other passengers. Bitter cold morning— The Stage drove through Dedham without stopping—and I lost the opportunity of leaving my Deed from James Baxter, with the Register to be recorded. We breakfasted at Fuller’s at Walpole— He told me my wife and family dined there yesterday. After daylight came, I recognized after some doubt Mr William H. Vernon as a fellow-passenger— He was equally hesitating in his recognition of me. We were fellow passengers in the Boston Frigate to France in February and March 1778— He was then a blooming and beautiful youth of twenty— I was a boy of scarce eleven— He has cheeks deeply furrowed with years and cares—mine much the same— He besieged me at once, about his claims upon the French Government; and talks of going to Washington this Winter— We reached Providence just at noon, and embarked in the Steam-boat President, Captain R. H. Bunker— My wife and family were already in the Boat— At half past two Mr Vernon disembarked at Newport— At four we doubled point Judith with a brisk Southwest wind— About 8 in the Evening we entered Long-Island Sound and had till past Midnight to buffet against a Southwestern gale, and a rapid tide— Mr Robert G. Shaw, and two of his daughters are passengers with us.
10. V:30. Saturday.— New-York.

The Gale subsided after Midnight, and I had some Sleep, without being conscious of it. I thought I had not closed my eyes the whole Night, but found on seeking for my shoes that they had been taken away, and a pair of Slippers left in their stead— The Boat reached the Courtland Street wharf, just before Sun rise— We could not obtain admittance at the City Hotel, and came to the American Hotel, kept by Mr Boardman, where we obtained not without difficulty a parlour and two bed-chambers— But were obliged to take for half the day the Parlour of Mr Charles Kemble the Comedian, who happened to be gone upon a visit to West-Point— I wrote to my Son Charles, and enclosed to him the Deed of James Baxter, to be recorded at Dedham, which I had been unable to leave there— John A. Smith, Mrs De Wint, with Miss Mary Verplanck, and a Mrs Hook Edmund H. Blunt and a Mrpaid us Morning visits— In the Evening we went to the Italian Opera, and saw Elisa & Claudio— Music by Mercadante—a very good performance— The Signora Pedrotti the Prima-donna is a Second rate Italian Cantatrice— Orchestra 30 performers good— Chorus voices not bad—there was an interlude performance on the Piano by Mr. L Major of the Conservatoire at Paris— We met at the Theatre Mr and Mrs. S. Brooks—C. King—D. Lynch, Mr Davis,—BibbyBowdoin—Pattersons—Ward, and some others.
11. VI:15. Sunday.

Mr George Sullivan came this Morning, and went with me to St Thomas Church where Mr Hawkes read prayers for the 21st. Sunday after Trinity, and preached a Sermon upon the atonement—from Acts 11.36. Mr Hawkes was a Lawyer in North-Carolina, who changed his profession and became a Clergyman. He is very eloquent, and uses elegant Language— His doctrines upon the atonement are of the most inflexible character; but he is said to have lost some of the affections of his flock, by deserting them last Summer, under a panic from the Cholera. After Church we visited the Ex-Chancellor Kent, who has removed since I was here last Fall— He told me he had written me a Letter yesterday— Viewed a new specimen of Architecture in a row of dwelling houses with Pillars of the composite order, resembling the Garde-Meubles du Roi at Paris. John A Smith dined with us—and went with me to the Dutch Church, where I heard not Dr Matthews but a Stranger, from 1 James 22–24. Dr Matthews was present in a Pew— We had Evening visitors—Charles King—Joseph, and Edmund H. Blunt—Mr and Mrs De Wint, and John A. Smith— Julia De Wint the second daughter is to go with us to Washington— She came, and is to lodge at this house this Night— Mr and Mrs S. L. Gouverneur, Mrs Hay and sundry other Visitors called upon us, but I was out when they came, and did not see them.
12. V. Monday— From New-York to Philadelphia.

Rose at five— Mr George Sullivan came and accompanied me to the Boat. John A. Smith came also; but remained to accompany my wife, and Julia De Wint to the other boat for Brunswick— Ours left the wharf precisely at six O’Clock— Mrs Pitts came with me— The boat we came in was the Water-witch: we came through the Narrows, and outside of Staten-Island—landed near Washington; took Stages which brought us about 14 Miles— Then the Cars of a Rail-road 13 Miles to Bordentown— There embarked in the Steam-boat Robert Morris, and landed at the Chesnut Street wharf at Philadelphia, at half past three in the afternoon— Nine hours and a half from New-York— Met on board the Boat Mr Bullard, member of the House of Representatives of the U.S. from Louisiana, with his wife and family— Several other persons in the Boat, who knew me— Eighteen Stages full of passengers both ways— The Rail-road Cars very comfortable and convenient— I came and took lodgings at the United States Hotel, Chesnut Street— Called on Mr John Sergeant, and spent two hours of the Evening with him and his family. Met Mr John Vaughan in the Street— Mr Joseph Reed and his brother Henry Reed came to Mr Sergeant’s while I was there— I met Coll. T. L. M’Kenney also, at the Railway Cars; returning to Philadelphia from an excursion for health.
13. V. Tuesday.

I found morning occupation before breakfast where it should with untiring perseverance be sought— Breakfasted at the common table, below. William S. Foster called to see me. at 10 I went to the Chesnut Street wharf and waited till the morning boat from Trenton came in— I expected in her my wife and family, but was disappointed—they came not. I returned to my Inn, under great anxiety, fearing that some accident had befallen them— Mr and Mrs N. Biddle came with a very earnest and cordial invitation to My wife and family, to take lodging at their house. As they had not arrived I engaged to dine with Biddle at 4. Visits from J. Connell, John Vaughan, Mr Cowperthwait, Mrs John Sergeant, and Dr John Hopkinson— I called at Mr Walsh’s, but he was not at home— At the Bank, and saw again Mr Biddle— Among the Newspapers there I found in the New-York Commercial Advertiser of yesterday, a favourable notice of Dermot with copious extracts from the Poem— At half past three P.M. I went again to the wharf and awaited the arrival of the Boat from Bordentown, and was again disappointed— The Captain had seen nor heard nothing of my family— I dined with Mr Biddle— Judge Hopkinson D. P. Brown, and Connell dined there— R. Peters came in after dinner— Brown told me he had quoted from Dermot, in an argument in Court this morning, “and Mercy, fitted for the Tyger’s den”—and shoot at a duck and hit a plover. I paid a visit to Mr Walsh; who has been ill, and did not venture to dine out. On returning to my lodgings I found my wife and family had arrived in the second afternoon boat from Bordentown.
14. IV.45. Wednesday.— From Philadelphia to Baltimore.

We left Philadelphia, in Steamer William Penn, Captain Jeffreys— Landed at Newcastle at ten. left the Carriage and Horses, with John Kirke and Mrs Nowlan to come on to-morrow— The rest of us cross’d in the Rail-road Cars to Frenchtown; in an hour and thirty-five minutes— They go sometimes in less than an hour— But a strong head-wind prevents the Steam in the locomotive from rising— At Frenchtown we took the Steamer Carroll of Carrollton, Captain Chaytor, and reached Baltimore, at 5. P.M— We transferred several passengers to the Boat going from Baltimore to Norfolk, which we met in the Bay; and learned the death of Mr Carroll, last of the Signers, this Morning. We took lodgings at Beltzhover’s— Passengers with us in the Steamers L. W. Tazewell—Ex-Senator U.S. having lately resigned his seat—Coll. Henderson of the Marine Corps, Roberts Vaux, Mrs Yturbide, Mrs Cone, and Multitudes of others— Evening visits from C. C. Woodward— Also a deputation of Mr Thomas and four other members of the City Council, inviting me to attend the funeral of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, on Saturday next. I requested them to return my respectful thanks to the Council, for the honour done me by this invitation, with assurance of my regret that my engagements required me to proceed to Washington to-morrow.
15. V:30. Thursday. From Baltimore to Washington

We left Baltimore at a quarter before nine this Morning, in the blue line of Stages, and descended at a quarter before two at my Son John’s House at Washington, at a quarter before two P.M— Thus favoured by the weather, and all other Circumstances we have accomplished our Journey, and found my Son his wife and child, in health, excepting the unfortunate condition of his eyes, which remain—nothing better than when he went with me to Philadelphia to take advice of Doctor Physick, in which we were disappointed by the Doctor’s absence at the time from Philadelphia— Upon this Calamity, I have yet only to pray for a relenting Providence— Coll. B. C. Howard, the member from Baltimore in the House of Representatives, and two other Gentlemen, were fellow-passengers with us in the Stage. Howard told us that a deputation from the City Council at Baltimore came this morning to invite the President and the Heads of Departments to attend the funeral of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, on Saturday— At Washington I found my writing chamber all ready for my reception, and spent part of the Evening in writing to my Son Charles, without finishing the Letter— The only resource that I find in the disappointments and discomforts of life is occupation— To keep the mind as constantly as possible employed— All before me is dreary— Let the world of Imagination be kept, as long as possible, cheery.
16. VI:15. Friday.

Finished my Letter to Charles— John Kirk arrived with the Carriage and Horses and Mrs Nowlan, who took leave of us—and returned to live with her Son in Law.— Mr Frye and his Son Thomas, Mr W. S. Smith Dr Huntt and Mr and Mrs Hawley came to see us. Mr Woodbury the Secretary of the Navy left Cards— I walked before dinner to the Race-ground— The rest of the day passed in that restless vacuity of mind, which attends the want of a fixed occupation— I composed two Miscellaneous Stanza’s of the Ottava Rima—and found in them the inanity of an unsettled subject. Read Byron’s Vision of Judgment—a profligate poem, like all the rest of that writer—but containing great Satyric power— Read also his translation of the first Canto of Pulci’s Morgante Maggiore—the first Model of this Style of Poetry— Admirable for Ironical Satire— Pity that it was not continued. The essence of this Poetry consists in its Satirical humour, so disguised, as to leave it doubtful what was the author’s real object of ridicule— To connect with this a real purpose of pure and profound morality, is a design equally worthy of a philosopher and a Poet.
17. VI.30. Saturday.

Took my heretofore accustomed walk round the Capitol before Breakfast. A slow rain confined me for the remainder of the day to the House— Wrote a short Letter, and wasted time in writing and reading— Resumed arrears of my Diary Index 17. May 1831.— Read again Byron’s Translation of Pulci—and his own Mazeppa— From two or three Sentences of Voltaire’s Charles the 12th. Byron has drawn out a tale, full of vivid description, of rapid narration, of foul and ferocious Passion, by which with a happy touch of the Satyric he makes the Hetman lull Charles to sleep after the Battle of Pultawa. The Basis of the Tale is Adultery— The overruling power of Love—and the transcendent Virtue of Fortitude in Adversity— The Magnanimity of enduring pain, and the relentless purpose of Revenge, embrace almost the whole of Byron’s Morality— The Riches of his Mind are inexhaustible— His observation of physical Nature more like intuition than perception— His remarks on men and manners, keen and penetrating, but always tinctured and discoloured by his own Vices— He saw of human nature nothing but its defects and infirmities, because he was always seeking palliatives for his own— My thoughts are wandering into vacuity, and I cannot collect them upon one point— I am wasting time
18. VI. Sunday

Heard Mr Hawley at St. John’s Church, where my Son John has purchased a pew. He preached from Proverbs 10.14. “Wise-men lay up knowledge; but the mouth of the foolish is near destruction.” Dull day and thin auditory— Visits from the Commandeur Torlade—Mr Munroe. W. S. Smith with Julia de Wint—Mrs Tudor and her Granddaughter; and Mr Fendall— In the afternoon, at the second Presbyterian Church Mr Smith preached from Matthew 15.21–28. the Story of the Syro-Phonician woman— In the Evening I had visits from General Scott, and Major Mercer— The General is alarmed at the prospect of being called to suppress the South-Carolina nullification— I began the reading of Gleig’s History of the Bible— Read also the Prisoner of Chillon, and the First Act of Marino Faliero— The delight which Byron took in painting human wretchedness is inconceivable to me— In the preface to Marino Faliero, he speaks of the Elopement of Dearbhargil, with MacMurchad— And Mrs Biddle shewed me at Philadelphia, among the Irish Melodies of Moore, a lament of O’Ruark Prince of Breffny, at the Infidelity of his wife— I knew nothing of either of these notices before— I am still composing miscellaneous Stanza’s at Random, and waiting for Inspiration—
19. V:30. Monday [symbols]

Morning visits from Mr Wyer and Judge Thruston. Wyer in a state of total despondency— The judge to solicit for his Son, Thomas Thruston, who is a Candidate for the Office of Sergeant at Arms to the House of Representatives— He is also a Candidate for the Office of Door keeper to the Senate— And the Judge solicits for him with his usual earnestness— I walked this morning round the Capitol; and returned by Cards left at his house, the visit of Mr Levi Woodbury Secretary of the Navy— The remainder of the day I employed in writing two short Letters journalizing—redeeming arrears of Diary Index, reading two Acts of Marino Faliero, and poetising upon trifles— The practise of composing while I walk is of inestimable value when I have a subject—but I have now none fixed, and the time, is something worse than lost— I looked into Cicero into Valerius Maximus, into Ovid for Ideas, to start a train of thought, but found nothing— Easy versification depends altogether upon practise— But Invention—Continuous combination of thought—usefulness of purpose—these are the difficulties which seem to be insuperable— It is my wish to fill every moment of my time with some action of the mind, which may contribute to the pleasure or the improvement of my fellow Creatures— This is the duty of our Nature— But there is too great disproportion between my purposes and my powers.
20. VI. Tuesday [symbols]

Walk round the Capitol, musing upon trash— Received from Matthew St. Clair Clarke, Clerk of the House of Representatives a printed invitation to attend the funeral of Philip Doddridge a member of the House from Virginia, who died suddenly last Evening at Brown’s Hotel. The funeral was to proceed from that house, at half past three— I then attended there, and found assembled a small number of persons, among whom were President Jackson—his Secretaries, Livingston, M’Lane, and Woodbury, the Postmaster General Barry—the Commissioner of the Land-Office Hayward, Senator Tyler and members of the house Wilde and White of Florida—Commodore Hull and Coll. Jones the Adjutant General. I took no notice of Jackson— Most of the others spoke to me— After some time Mr Clarke announced that many of the Citizens were anxious to have a likeness of the deceased taken and the funeral was therefore postponed till ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning.— I came home, and went with Mrs Adams, Mrs Frye, who had dined with us, and John’s wife, and spent the Evening at Mr T. B. Johnson’s. Mrs W. S. Smith and Julia de Wint were there but did not stay.— Mr Frye soon came in— We played a rubber of Whist. Mr Johnson is in feeble health. Mr Doddridge was here as a member of a Committee of Congress to prepare a Code of Laws for the District.
21. VI. Wednesday

At ten this Morning I went again to Brown’s Hotel, and thence attended the funeral of Philip Doddridge. Mr White of Florida rode with me to the Cemetery at the Eastern Branch of the Potomack, where the remains were deposited, with a short prayer by Mr Post— Mr White told me the melancholy circumstances of the illness and death of Mr Doddridge. None of his family are here— The grave-yard has been laid out in alleys since last Summer. Leaving Mr White at his house, on my return home I found Mr Johnson here. Mr and Mrs White, afterwards paid us a visit— I lent them my copy of Dermot, which they both had much curiosity to see— General Macomb paid us also a long evening visit— I received this Morning Letters from Drake Mills, with a diagram of a projected perpetual motion—from N. Biddle, with enclosures: from Mortimer R. Talbot—from Charles Bowen, with a copy of the Token, or Atlantic Souvenir for 1833 and from W. B. Sloan—all deserving sober reflection— The last one of the Tantalizing incidents of my trial— I answered Sloan’s Letter, and wrote to Mr Lord— Sloan is a Stranger to me; and whether his Letter is a freak of enthusiasm or a hoax is problematic to me— My Conversations and my anticipations are distressing.
22. VI. Thursday.

Rain, great part of the day— Postponed my walk round the Capitol till after Breakfast.— Answered a Letter from my old Classmate Daniel Mayo, and that from Charles Bowen— I promised to send him an Article for his next years Token— And I began a Letter in answer to that of N. Biddle— I read the Appendix to the Tragedy of Marino Faliero, and part of the Tragedy of Manfred. The Story of the Venetian Doge is extraordinary, and his conspiracy must be classed among the cases of Great Events proceeding from trifling causes— The Drama, is sufficiently true to the History, and the developement of Passion is marked with invention not transcending the bounds of probability and with language elegant and energetic— A conspiracy to destroy a Government, by the man at its head—a Man of fourscore years of age—for a cause so slight, is a phenomenon in History— A slanderous sarcasm upon his wife—insufficiently punished in his estimation as the sole ground for his attempt to overthrow the Government, and make himself the Supreme Lord of Venice— It is scarcely less extraordinary that Byron should expose with so much indignation the corruption, consisting in a licentious intercourse of the Sexes— Manfred is a production of a different character. I see it sometimes represented as the greatest effort of Byron’s Genius— My Lucubrations are teazing—delusive—and abortive.
23. VI. Friday.

The walk round the Capitol before Breakfast, seems a necessary of Life to me, when at Washington; and then the want of occupation during the walk is another. Thus it was that the Poem of Dermot was composed, and it is now matter of surprize to myself, how it was fashioned into the shape which it finally assumed— I want a similar subject now; but invention is barren, and I have a repugnance to the further use of the Ottava Rima Stanza— Dr Huntt was here and told some appalling Stories of the ravages of the Cholera while it was prevailing here. It is now raging with tremendous fury at New-Orleans, and the yellow fever with it— Dr Huntt hinted to me that my complaint might become a fistula— But how to guard against it— I read Byron’s Tragedy of Manfred; in three Acts— There is a vapour of mystery cast around, the Story, which seems to be considered as constituting the Sublime— There is no action in the poem— Manfred talks much—evokes a succession of Supernatural Spirits— Commands them all despotically—Disdains obedience to any of them—but he does nothing but die—and there is no reason given why he dies then, rather than seven years before, or seven years after— Galt says that Byron affected to raise dark suspicions that there was some horrible reality in his own life like that pourtrayed with the Story of Manfred— He was a “Fanfaron de Crimes.”
24. VI.15. Saturday.

Walk round the Capitol before Breakfast, and finished a poetical trifle which has teazed me for several days— I am sufficiently disoccupied for the mind to feed itself with anticipation of evil— As I have not the power to avert them, my resource is to escape from them when possible. This is what I am now endeavouring to do, with little success; for the want of a continuous subject of meditation— My time is almost totally uninterrupted, and day after day passes without a Solitary visitor— This is my happiest state of existence—but it needs an occupied mind— I answered a Letter from N. Biddle; and with more difficulty one from Drake Mills a man at New-York, who thinks he has discovered a perpetual motion but is not sure whether he has or not. He confides his secret to me; and asks my opinion of it— I advise him to have the same confidence in some honest Mechanic employ him to make a model of his invention, and try the experiment— I read the first and part of the second Canto of Byron’s Corsair—written and published in 1814 a year before his Marriage— Desperate Courage, inflexible Fortitude, and contempt of pain and death, were the darling Virtues of Byron’s Imagination— His Love was gross sensuality mingled with ferocious tenderness romantic sentimentality, and a total disregard of all moral restraint— The Love of a Cat Tyger.
25. VI:15. Sunday.

Heard at St. John’s Church this Morning, Mr Brooks of Georgetown from 1. Timothy 1.15. He read prayers for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity— His text—“This is a faithful saying and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save Sinners; of whom I am the chief.”— This too was a Sermon upon the atonement. The Clergy of the Episcopal Church at present preach upon scarcely anything else— All practical religion to them is swallowed up in the Trinity and the Atonement— There was no Church at St. John’s in the afternoon, Mr Hawley being engaged to attend the funeral of Mr Moore. I heard Mr Smith at the Presbyterian Church; from Matthew 16.–13–20. The discourse of Christ with his disciples; concerning whom he was said to be— It struck me as singular that the result of Mr Smith’s analysis of this whole passage, was an argument against the pretensions of the Bishop of Rome, to any pre-eminence as the Successor of St. Peter— The organization and the operations of the mind are incomprehensible. Mr Smith said that the expression of Son of Man, was equivalent to that of a descendant of Adam; and that Jesus, was speaking of himself in his human capacity. I read a Chapter of Gleig’s History of the Bible. One of the Harper Family Library Publications; suitable for this day’s reading— Mr John Connell spent the Evening here— Come to attend the Danish Commission— John and his wife at Mr Frye’s— I wrote to Charles
26. VII. Monday.

My wife was very unwell, with a return of the Erisypelas My morning walk was barren— Mark Stokes is an Englishman, a Gardener by trade, and brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Michlam, my Taylor when I was last in England. Stokes has claims to property in North-Carolina and other parts of the United States from an Uncle, who died some years since in this Country, and wished me to recommend to him a Solicitor to prosecute them. He exhibited to me several documents; a genealogy and his father’s Will—but that of his Uncle from whom he claims was missing— He said he had it and would bring it to me. I called upon Mrs Tudor, and conversed with her respecting her projected petition to Congress— She is yet entirely without Evidence of her husband’s term of Service as Judge Advocate— She is to endeavour to procure a copy of Captain Henley’s printed trial. Mr Penci is an Italian fencing-Master, who came to consult me, on the expediency of undertaking the establishment of a gymnastic School in Washington— I told him I thought he would be likelier to succeed in a larger City— He said he had one in Baltimore. I finished reading Byron’s Corsair— “One virtue and a thousand Crimes” would be a suitable Motto for all Byrons works.
27. VI:15. Tuesday.

Before rising, and in my walk round the Capitol Hill this Morning I attempted the Commencement of an Elegy—but the stream had no fountain and ran immediately dry— I returned visits to the Commandeur Torlade d’Azambuja, Portuguese Chargé d’Affaires of the King Don Miguel— He has his Portrait in his Parlour, which he told me was a very strong likeness and observed that it did not look like a Tyrant. He spoke also very gratefully of the contributions from Massachusetts for the Inhabitants of the Cape de Verd Islands, suffering by famine. I called also to see Mrs W. S. Smith, but she was not at home— Left Cards at Mr T. Munroe’s and at General Macomb’s— Wrote 3 short Letters— I received one from Melvin Lord, saying that appearances indicated the probable demand for a second Edition of Dermot, and asking for a corrected copy of the Poem— But the prospects of its reception are still ambiguous and tantalizing— I cannot realize that even the first Edition will be sold— I read Lord Byron’s Lara— Said by some of his Commentators, I know not why to be a sequel to his Corsair— It is another Tale, told in the same manner—but without any connection between the two Stories— Poetically Conrad and Lara are twins; and so are Medora and Kaled— There is no similarity in their adventures.
28. IV.15. Wednesday.

My wife is ill with a very violent attack of Erisypelas which has been coming upon her these four days— This afternoon we sent for Dr Huntt who came and bled her, and gave her medicines of severe operation— Late this Evening she was extremely sick— My walk round the Capitol was barren— I answered a Letter from Benjamin Cowell of Providence, Rhode-Island, who has sent me a copy of an Address to an Anti-Masonic Convention there on the second of this Month— Also a Letter from Joseph Leary of New-York who requests me to write a preface to a Stereotype Edition of the Declaration of Independence the Constitution of the United States, and Washington’s farewell address— I read Lord Byron’s Bride of Abydos and part of his Parisina— One remarkable peculiarity in him, is his choice of Subjects— Most of them are to me disgusting— He has great fertility of thought but not much imagination— He is always wallowing in the mire of sensuality, and repeats himself perpetually— His Don Juan and Haidee is a mere copy of Conrad and Gulnare, and it seems as if he could write nothing without an incest.
29. V:30. Thursday.

Mrs Adams continues confined to her bed with the Erisypelas, or inflammable rhumatic fever— John’s eldest child Louisa, is this day likewise ill—sick and feverish. I called this Morning at Gadsby’sHotel to see J. Connell, but he was already out— E. Wyer whom I met there took the papers of Frederick Soper, and engaged to deliver them to Connell— A Mr Boyd came to me to announce himself as a Candidate for the appointment of Sergeant at Arms to the House of Representatives. He said he had been one the persons who destroyed the frigate Philadelphia at Tripoli— I told him I had been applied to by many other Candidates; and could take no engagement in favour of any one— I met this morning Mr Daniel of Kentucky, in my return from walking round the Capitol. Had morning visits from Mr Vinton of Ohio, and Mr Allan of Kentucky; Members of the House. I called at the War-Office— Presented to the Secretary Lewis Cass the order of Jonathan Hill, for his discharge from the Army after the close of the Revolutionary War in 1783—and the papers sent me by Thomas Vinson, to support his claim for a pension as a Revolutionary Officer— Next I went to the General Land-Office— The Commissioner was out, but I left with the Chief Clerk the Land-warrant for the heirs of Sylvester Holmes— Wrote to R. Rush, and read Beppo.
30. VI:30. Friday.

My wife is still severely ill, without abatement in the symptoms of her disease— Suffering extreme pain, and with the face swollen and inflamed almost to closure of the eyes. The child Louisa too continues very unwell— In my morning walk I called at Gadsby’s Hotel, and saw Mr Connell, who gave me the information which I desired respecting the claim of Frederick Soper— The Danish Commission take no cognizance of Seamen’s wages— Mr Charles Nagy a Hungarian Patriot brought me a Letter of Introduction from General La Fayette— I had a morning visit from Mr Brent, Chief Clerk of the Department of State— Dr Huntt was here to visit his two Patients; and Mr and Mrs Frye called in the afternoon—and Mr Lawrence in the Evening— He is here upon some claim before the Danish Commission— I wrote several Letters; but the pressure upon my Spirits from the illness of my wife and grand child at once, with all the other prospects before and around me, is more than I can endure and reduces me to the weakness of a child. And it is a childhood from which there is no recovery— No release but by death— It seems to me that Indian torture, roasting to Death by a slow fire would differ little from the condition that awaits me.
